Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Exploiting Side Information: a New Role of Feedback

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Traditionally, feedback has been mainly used in communication systems for retransmission and for channel prediction. Several recent results in network information theory have identified a new role for feedback: exploiting side information to mitigate interference. Due to the broadcast nature of communication media, information intended for one user is often received by other users. Feedback can be used to exploit this side information to improve the efficiency of future transmissions. The proposed work builds upon these results to come up with a theory unifying the existing isolated results as well as broadening to more scenarios of interest. It will also identify specific problems to solve for realizing this new role of feedback in practice. The goal is to close the gap between feedback research in information theory and the design of feedback mechanisms in practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Communication is typically bi-directional. An interesting question is whether the fundamental limit of two-way communicatuion differs from the sum of two separate one-way communication channels? Claude E. Shannon, the father of information theory, first asked that question in the 1960's, and showed that in many cases, the answer is no. A central problem asked in this project is the analogous question in the case when two pairs of users want to talk to each other while interfering with each other. Can two-way communication in an interference-limited scenario be more efficiently done than treating the two directions separately? This is the central question asked in this project. The main outcome of the project is a complete answer to this question, the exact characterization of the capacity region of a representative two-way interference channel.

One major different between Shannon's point to point setting and our interference setting is the role of feedback. Shannon showed that feedback cannot increase the capacity of one-way point-to-point channels. In contrast, we had showed in earlier work that feedback can give significant gain in interference channel by providing side information to interfering users. This suggests that in two-way interference channels, there is an interesting dual role of the transmission of a user: to carry its own data traffic, as well as to provide feedback to the other user's transmission. Our characterization gives the optimal way of how these two funxtions can be optimally carried out simultaneously. Interesting, it turns out that in some regimes, communication can be done optimally such that  one approaches the capacity under feedback  for both directions simultaneously. Thus, feedback can be performed for the other party without hurting the data transmission in this direction at all. Thus, one can have the cake, and eat it too.
